title: 106_hr5293
content: Aliens convicted of an aggravated felony or a firearm offense will be rendered inadmissible. Aliens convicted of aggravated felonies or firearm offenses are inadmissible, unless granted a full pardon by the President or Governor. Aliens convicted of firearm offenses are inadmissible under this law, with the amendment applying to convictions entered after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 2. LIMITATION ON WAIVER OF INADMISSIBILITY FOR CRIMINAL ALIENS UNLAWFULLY PRESENT IN THE UNITED STATES. The amendment to Section 212(h) of the Immigration and Nationality Act restricts waivers for aliens convicted of aggravated felonies or those not residing continuously in the US for at least 7 years before removal proceedings. Effective immediately for waivers granted after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Inadmissibility and ineligibility for finding of good moral character for aliens who make misrepresentations to procure benefits for others. Amendments are made to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding inadmissibility and ineligibility for good moral character for those who make misrepresentations to procure benefits for themselves or others. The changes apply to misrepresentations made after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act by removing a reference to section 212(a)(2) for cancellation of removal. The amendment applies to ongoing proceedings after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5 addresses the detention and release of criminal aliens pending removal decisions. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act allows for the arrest and detention of aliens pending removal decisions if alleged by the Attorney General. It does not mandate the arrest or detention of aliens sentenced to imprisonment until their release. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act allows for the arrest and detention of aliens pending removal decisions if alleged by the Attorney General. The Attorney General may release an alien under this paragraph only on bond of at least $2,000 with security. The amendments made by paragraph (1) shall apply to aliens who are in proceedings under the Immigration and Nationality Act on or after the date of the enactment of this Act if those proceedings have not resulted in a final administrative order before such date. The amendment allows for the release of aliens pending removal decisions on a bond of at least $2,000 with approved security conditions by the Attorney General. This amendment applies to releases occurring after the enactment of the Act.
